Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Arabidopsis 2010: Ecological genomics of adaptation to climate
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research investigates the ecological and genetic mechanisms that allow the plant Arabidopsis thaliana to adapt (grow, survive and reproduce) to different natural environments. Using wild populations from the extremes of a natural gradient in temperature and length of daylight, the investigators will identify the traits and genes that govern plant performance in nature. Traits of particular interest include flowering time, freezing and drought tolerance, and the capacity of plants to photosynthesize (make energy from sunlight) under conditions of physiological stress. The investigators will identify the genes that contribute to adaptation in nature and the magnitude of the effect of individual genes. A major goal of this work is to investigate the importance of genes that have positive effects in one environment but negative effects in other environments. Such genes are poorly understood but are thought to play a key role in adaptation.

The study will provide a deeper understanding of the mechanisms that allow plants to cope with different environments and has the potential to provide genetic tools for producing new varieties of plants/crops. In addition, the study system is well suited to investigate the possible consequences of global climate change and the potential of plants to adapt to rapidly changing conditions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research investigated the genetic and physiological basis of local adaptation to climate across the natural range of Arabidopsis. As described above, the experimental approach of growing mapping populations in native environments identified genomic regions underlying fitness tradeoffs, where alleles showed positive effects on fitness in one environment but negative effects in the other. The results from our first 3 years were published in Ågren et al. 2013.

We have used studies of the Italy x Sweden mapping populations in controlled conditions to identify QTL for drought related traits and found that they colocalize with fitness QTL. We have a manuscript in preparation on these results (Mojica et al. in prep.) In addition, we have investigated drought adaptation from diverse collections of Arabidopsis. This includes efforts to understand the physiological mechanisms of drought adaptation (Easlon et al. 2014) and to incorporate genetic variation into physiological models (Reuning et al. 2015). To connect back to specific mutations, we have used targeted and whole genome resequencing and analysis (Lovell et al. 2013, Lowry et al. 2013) to create a catalog of all of the variants segregating in our mapping populations. We then associated these variants with climatic variation across the species range (Lasky et al. 2012, Lovell et al. 2013, Lasky et al. 2015 Other research included a comparison of the degree of adaptation to climate in sexual versus asexual populations of Boechera spatifolia (Lovell et al. 2014) development of a new reduced representation sequencing approach (Wang et al 2012), and a protocol for developing genome-wide near-isogenic lines (NILs) (Fletcher et al. 2013).

This project provided training for one postdoc, one technician, one visiting scientist, two PhD students, and two REU students in experimental and statistical aspects of quantitative genetics, population genetics and bioinformatics. In addition, we also provided a formal professional development and research mentoring program that benefitted 20 undergraduate students from 5 Universities. this project supported John Lovell worked on the project as a PhD student in the McKay lab. He received an NSF-PGI postdoctoral fellowship and is now in the Juenger lab at UT Austin. McKay led a graduate training course (30 students) and symposium (140 scientists) on the Genetics of Adaptation at Uppsala University. The implications of our findings on the importance of local adaptation towards species conservation were presented at a Conservation Genomics meeting, and in a publication (Funk et al 2012).

Data and resource sharing-- We resequenced both parents used to produce the mapping population and conducted a de novo and reference based assembly. A manuscript, cataloging the difference between these genomes, with a focus on large effect mutations in QTL is in preparation, and all reads will be deposited at the NCBI sequence read archive. We plan to use an existing genome browser (Rutgers Plant Browser) to share the entirety of the sequence, genotype, and QTL information from our publications. Data for CBF sequences generated by Sanger sequencing thus far, along with additional sequence generated from the proposed work, will be submitted to BankIt at NCBI upon publication.

Dissemination of results-- McKay presented this research in 27 invited talks since the award was made. 

Publications-- To date, the McKay lab has published 10 papers from this NSF-supported research. Three more papers are in preparation.
